headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome to Wynn Resorts Fourth Quarter and Year Ended 2009 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call on behalf of the company today are Steve Wynn; Marc Schorr; John Strzemp; Matt Maddox; Andrew Pascal, President of Wynn Las Vegas; and
componenttext: Good afternoon and welcome to Wynn Resorts Fourth Quarter and Year Ended 2009 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call on behalf of the company today are Steve Wynn; Marc Schorr; John Strzemp; Matt Maddox; Andrew Pascal, President of Wynn Las Vegas; and on the phone, Ian Coughlan, President of Wynn Macau. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Matt Maddox. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Before we get started, I just need to remind everybody we will be making forward-looking statements under the Safe Harbor federal securities laws and those may or may not come true. With that, I'm going to turn it
componenttext: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Before we get started, I just need to remind everybody we will be making forward-looking statements under the Safe Harbor federal securities laws and those may or may not come true. With that, I'm going to turn it over to Steve Wynn for opening comments.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Hello to our investors and analysts and hi to our competitors. What we have to say, I think, is going to be very brief because I think these numbers speak for themselves. We had a wonderful year in China. We always want to point out that the most importan
componenttext: Hello to our investors and analysts and hi to our competitors. What we have to say, I think, is going to be very brief because I think these numbers speak for themselves. We had a wonderful year in China. We always want to point out that the most important thing to recognize when looking at numbers in our business is not so much market share per se. That's a measurement of sort of casino revenue.  What really is important is to look at the yield per table and the profitability per table. And I'm very happy to see that again, for the second or third consecutive year, the profitability and the efficiency of our tables in Macau have continued to climb in spite of the existence of some very fanciful competition that appeared this year. The Macau market is beginning to show some maturity. There are fine buildings that have been opened and are being operated. And as market conditions have improved, I think that the rest of the construction that was started and temporarily halted will now continue. That's all good news as we go forward in having that market be mature. We've happily established a niche for ourselves and I think our EBITDA was over $500 million last year. And although I don't make forward-looking statements as a rule, we're tracking substantially ahead of that the first two months of the year. And we haven't even opened Encore, which is about 60 or 90 days away. I think it went to April 24, on a Wednesday. I think Linda decided that we'll do it in April 24, and that is the most beautiful thing we've ever done. And when that kicks in, we're going to have another little boost in our ability to understand and serve the specific needs of our customers. And our customers are, admittedly, the top end. This building, Encore in Macau, and I'm taking just an extra minute or two to comment on it, is a building that was designed after we had two years of experience to understand the needs of our particular guests that gamble and visit Macau. When we built Wynn Macau and opened it in '06, we had done our very best in pre-opening research and design to have a building that would appeal to what we understood to be that market. And I'm happy to say that we weren't very far off the mark and the success that we have enjoyed is a direct reflection of the fact that we were able to get it right, especially in the wonderful employees that we were able to attract to come work for us. The workforce in Macau is totally delicious. I mean, the people that have come to work for us from Macau, from Mainland China, from the Philippines have the most wonderful desire to be trained and to improve and be successful in their jobs. That's probably been our main asset, it's the people that work for us, which is why we never cut back on salaries or the 13th month, or why we never did any of the other things that some of our competitors have done. Because whether it's in Macau or Las Vegas, our principal asset are our employees, period. And the ones we have now in China are just absolutely over the moon. Wonderful, as far as we're concerned. And we have the organization that's going to be in place to open Encore. I'm happy to say in a few months -- and I think when everybody gets a whiff of that place, they're going to realize that we've set a new standard in hospitality, facilities and the way we present our product. It is by far the best thing that I've been part of and I've been doing this for 40 odd years. It's 414 rooms and suites and I'm very excited about April's opening and can't wait to share it with everybody. So much for Macau. We look forward to a very healthy and exciting 2010 and beyond. I wish I could say the same thing about Las Vegas. But I'm still -- as we have been in the past, unlike some of our competitors who've seen all kinds of glitter and wonderment from just around the corner, I think everybody sort of come clean now that we don't see that. The policies in Washington, policies of government, have taken a terrible toll on the working people in America that come to Las Vegas on the corporations that book conventions and meetings in Las Vegas. I'm afraid to say that I think the outlook for 2010 is very conservative, at least. I don't see any major change in the future. I don't see it getting worse per se, but I do think that unless there is some signal from Washington that they can control the deficit that, not only Las Vegas but the country, it faces dire problems. And I don't see any reason whatsoever to have a speck of confidence in the congress or the administration that's there now. And in the end, Las Vegas is almost a perfect reflection of the national mood. So I'm conservative and guarded about the future of Las Vegas, and I think political leadership has now come home to roost as part of every businessman's conference calls.  I mean, imagine that it would be necessary for someone in my position with my job to talk to a group of investors and analysts and have to refer to policies in Washington when discussing the relevance of the quarters that lie ahead. If anybody's got a speck of sophistication, it's listening to my voice now but recognize that, that is, in fact, true. I'll take questions and so will my colleagues who are sitting around the table.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Joe Greff with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Joe Greff with JPMorgan.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: If you could help us maybe, Matt, on the net hold impact in Macau and Las Vegas from an EBITDA perspective? And then you referenced in earnings release in the quarter, corporate expense had some one-time items you could help us understand what that amount
componenttext: If you could help us maybe, Matt, on the net hold impact in Macau and Las Vegas from an EBITDA perspective? And then you referenced in earnings release in the quarter, corporate expense had some one-time items you could help us understand what that amount was and what that relates to?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. In Las Vegas we held about an 18.7%.  If we had been in the midpoint of our range, that would've been an approximately $15 million of additional EBITDA, had we held 22%. In Macau, you'll notice we only held $2.7 million, which is at the low end of o
componenttext: Sure. In Las Vegas we held about an 18.7%.  If we had been in the midpoint of our range, that would've been an approximately $15 million of additional EBITDA, had we held 22%. In Macau, you'll notice we only held $2.7 million, which is at the low end of our range, so I'll normalize it for you. But it's the low end of the range on the VIP side, where as normalized, it would be $2.85 million, which is a lot of money in Macau. $17 billion of turnover versus $11 billion of turnover last year, volumes are very strong. If you look at the corporate expense side, for full year 2008 we had about $36 million of corporate expense excluding the quarters. Full year '09, closer to $45 million. The difference of roughly a $8 million or $9 million is attributable to one-time payments related to the Macau IPO. So '09 corporate expenses would've been roughly flat with 2008 outside of those one-time expenses.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Matt or Steve, can you just talk about, in Macau or Las Vegas, collections of credit? And if you could help us understand or refresh us, and I know you do have a probably more conservative job of reserving that, but if you can talk about any changes in co
componenttext: Matt or Steve, can you just talk about, in Macau or Las Vegas, collections of credit? And if you could help us understand or refresh us, and I know you do have a probably more conservative job of reserving that, but if you can talk about any changes in collections there...

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I'm glad you brought that up. I know who's on this call so I'm going to talk of all them including my competitors. One of the things that has been really cute about this business of quarterly conference calls is sort of a game of cat and mouse about
componenttext: Joe, I'm glad you brought that up. I know who's on this call so I'm going to talk of all them including my competitors. One of the things that has been really cute about this business of quarterly conference calls is sort of a game of cat and mouse about credit. This company, Wynn Resorts, has a policy that originates in our audit committee, that is consistent with Sarbanes-Oxley, that is iron-fisted tough about the credit, credit reserves and credit accountability. And you've noticed that in my, I think, almost 40 odd years of experience, we've never had a special charge. It wasn't reserved in advance. That's the result of very, very tough whole-blooded assessment of credit when we issue it and when we create our original reserves. Matt, if you or Scott or anybody who wants to talk about our credit reserves and our experiences...

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll just jump in. In Las Vegas, we're over approximately 45% reserves. And in Macau, almost over 60%. So much higher than, I think, what is normally considered industry-standard.
componenttext: I'll just jump in. In Las Vegas, we're over approximately 45% reserves. And in Macau, almost over 60%. So much higher than, I think, what is normally considered industry-standard.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: And if we have a problem, it's that our auditors are saying, now just a minute, boys, don't be trying to create savings accounts, we know you're collecting this money. Well, we don't create savings accounts, that's not permitted by law. But what we do mak
componenttext: And if we have a problem, it's that our auditors are saying, now just a minute, boys, don't be trying to create savings accounts, we know you're collecting this money. Well, we don't create savings accounts, that's not permitted by law. But what we do make sure is that we don't have special charges. You see that in everyone of these other companies. I don't know, whether it's because they want to have fancy quarterly earnings when they don't really have fancy quarterly earnings. But I find that subject to be a bore. We reserve appropriately. And in my entire career, I've never had a special assessment because of a bad credit decision, and we don't have any now.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: My final question, Stephen, if you just talk about how you're viewing your Philadelphia opportunity, how that property would be positioned in Chicago by amenities, hotel rooms, maybe everything about projects scope, CapEx, any kind of details on that. I k
componenttext: My final question, Stephen, if you just talk about how you're viewing your Philadelphia opportunity, how that property would be positioned in Chicago by amenities, hotel rooms, maybe everything about projects scope, CapEx, any kind of details on that. I know it may be early, but anything you could share with that would be great.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: It is early, but I've spent the last several weeks, working almost eight, nine hours a day on the program with my partner, DeRuyter Butler, who have designed all these hotels with me. We do our in-house. I'm happy to say that we're feeling very good about
componenttext: It is early, but I've spent the last several weeks, working almost eight, nine hours a day on the program with my partner, DeRuyter Butler, who have designed all these hotels with me. We do our in-house. I'm happy to say that we're feeling very good about our opportunity in Philadelphia. It's not going to be a hotel, it's going to be the cutest casino that you've ever seen. It's not going to look like slots in a box. It's going to have a very definite Wynn signature presentation. It's going to be extraordinarily and very innovatively user-friendly. And it's going to have all the bells and whistles that are good-looking, fun, casino, restaurant complex with slot machines and table games and other forms of fun should have. And I think that's provocative and self-serving enough for the moment.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Woronka with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Woronka with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe you can talk a little bit about strategy on the foray in Las Vegas because if the theory is correct, then it's a very slow recovery. How do you look at trying to remake that business bringing back the higher end customer with room rates where they a
componenttext: Maybe you can talk a little bit about strategy on the foray in Las Vegas because if the theory is correct, then it's a very slow recovery. How do you look at trying to remake that business bringing back the higher end customer with room rates where they are right now?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Good question, really to the heart of the matter. If we have a rather cold-blooded look at the near future, the question is, what do you do then? And once again, here is the oldest story in the book when it comes to our company. Capital structure is your
componenttext: Good question, really to the heart of the matter. If we have a rather cold-blooded look at the near future, the question is, what do you do then? And once again, here is the oldest story in the book when it comes to our company. Capital structure is your salvation. It's capital structure that allows you to hold your head in a down market. I am not forced with my colleagues to juggle my employees or to juggle my customer service levels. There's nothing left to do in my industry except do the basics better. And doing the basics better is what we're all about right now as we tend to our flock in a market that's sort of rough. So we're building a $67 million beach club and a new nightclub to add to our existing nightclubs called Surrender. And we're improving Swith, our restaurant, that will all be integrated into the Encore beach club. And it's going to open up on May 21, we've got 90 days to go. It's right on schedule. And the Encore Beach Club will be -- and just as our nightclubs' excess in tryst have dominated the market, The Encore Beach Club will take this very profitable sector of the market, the alcoholic beverage recreational tumult that goes along with nightclubs. And the margins are fabulous. We have 65% profit margins in these departments, so better than Blackjack in many respects. Encore Beach Club will take the nightclub mentality into daytime. We've got this gorgeous two-level cabana club that would encore the north end of our property and liven up this end of the Strip. And you can walk from the cabanas out onto a French balcony and look over the Strip. Or on the inside, the cabanas look down on the pool area, which is integrated with the new nightclub, Surrender, and our restaurant, Switch, which will now have a beautiful terrace dining area. This whole complex, which is on the Strip side of Encore where we originally put up portraiture. Unfortunately, the hotels that were supposed to be built across the street from us at the Frontier site and at the Stardust site have been aborted. And we perceived that they will be aborted for the near and distant future. I don't see anything happening with the Echelon Place project in the near future nor do I see anything happening on the Frontier project. So having a fancy portraiture, which we unfortunately built for Encore, was worthless. Now another company would have to live with that. But because we have such a strong financial statement and because we have the working capital that's necessary to keep us competitive, we take off that unused portraiture and we put something on it that would generate profits in 90 days. And that puts more pressure on our competition, more pressure on every level of our competition. We're about to refurbish our rooms in Wynn because they're five years old. It puts more pressure on our competition because our service levels and the targeted attractiveness of our facilities gets more and more effective. Nothing left to do but the basics better. And that's the story of Wynn Resorts in Las Vegas.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Kent with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Kent with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: First on Philadelphia, to Joe's question earlier, can you give us a little bit more detail? Because I think one of our theories about you going into a market like Pennsylvania, is that -- on the one hand, you want to give a very Wynn experience, a great e
componenttext: First on Philadelphia, to Joe's question earlier, can you give us a little bit more detail? Because I think one of our theories about you going into a market like Pennsylvania, is that -- on the one hand, you want to give a very Wynn experience, a great experience, a great property. On the other hand, it does have a higher tax rate and it's hard to see how you could get a return that you historically have been comfortable with. So how do you balance putting your name on something that might not have sort of the same appeal? And I guess when I look over my history of looking at the industry, there've been times where people have entered Detroit or Pennsylvania or Mississippi where they've overspent and sort of -- how do you balance that or what constraints you? Then the second is, because Steve, you just mentioned that you could put a lot of pressure on your competition, which I agree you could. Can you talk about Vegas pricing? You're certainly leader here on pricing. You could stay at these rates and put pressure on the rest of the Strip. At the same time, again, given what is a superior experience, if you discount for too long, don't you teach your customers that they can get a great experience for half off or whatever the pricing is right now?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the second part of the question first because it's fresh in my mind. The danger that you described is real. Rates stay down in Las Vegas. How long do rates stay down in Las Vegas would be before they become the norm? You asked me that question
componenttext: Let me take the second part of the question first because it's fresh in my mind. The danger that you described is real. Rates stay down in Las Vegas. How long do rates stay down in Las Vegas would be before they become the norm? You asked me that question, and I say to you, I don't know. But what should I do? Have empty rooms? Can you hear me alright, Steve?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can hear you, Steve.
componenttext: Yes, I can hear you, Steve.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: you make a very valid point. But there you are. The revenues gone up by 3% and capacity's going up by over 6%, thanks to our friends down the street. Those buildings were conceived in a different time, but they exist. So does Encore. So we'd make the best
componenttext: you make a very valid point. But there you are. The revenues gone up by 3% and capacity's going up by over 6%, thanks to our friends down the street. Those buildings were conceived in a different time, but they exist. So does Encore. So we'd make the best of it. I'll tell you one thing, you better damn well have a strong balance sheet if you want to play on this Strip. And we've got one. I think our cash is equal to our debt. And we don't have any current maturities. We have long maturities, low interest rates. We're protected for stormy weather. And this is again -- I said this before, if you don't understand the capital structures, the backbone of your marketing, then you need to go back to business school. We understand that here. We don't need to learn that lesson anew. Now let's go back to Philadelphia, if we can, Steve. I'm building 3,000 slot machines and a bunch of table games and a poker room, Italian restaurant, a steak house, an Asian restaurant because I'm two blocks from a Vietnamese neighborhood, I'm five blocks from Society Hill, I'm in a town with seven universities, I'm about four blocks from the Walt Whitman Bridge, my 14 or 15 acres is on the Delaware River -- and incidentally, Steve, the almost to the foot, the same size as my property in Macau. Two blocks away or four blocks away is Walt Whitman Bridge. On the other side of the bridge is Cherry Hill, New Jersey, all full of my old friends, Italians and Jews and every conceivable stripe of ethnic group that love to shoot crap and gamble. And they're 10 minutes away in their cars or on a bus from my casino on the Delaware River. I love the proximity to these people. I love the proximity to the Vietnamese neighborhood, and I'm going to put in a beautiful Vietnamese restaurant for them. I'm going to build a very pretty place with the help of my Wynn design and development team that is perfectly responsive just to that market and not a bit more over the top than that. But it will look like us. It won't be a slots in a box. I spent some time this past week with a very good friend of mine, Bob Manoukian, who has, it's called, Philadelphia Parks Casino. And Bob was sharing the results of that casino with me. And I assure you, sir, that is not a below-average return on investment. It is a wonderful return on investment because of the low cost of marketing. Now listen, no Gulfstream jets, no helicopters, no nothing. And the table games and the slot wins are allowing, because of the limited amount of machines in the market, for returns that are handsome, much better than we can get in Las Vegas at the present moment. So I'm not concerned about overshooting the mark. I think we can build a lovely single-level, what would appears to be a single-level on the outside, you put the valet parking and the employee parking on grade and then you lift the casino by 12 or 14 feet and you drive up to that on the portraiture so it looks like it's on grade. And then you have two or three levels of parking on either side of the casino so you can walk right into the casino from the garages. And we make this super friendly place for users. And they can run in, gamble for 3 hours and run out, have a great steak or an Italian dinner or noodles or a slice of pizza and it will be just the right lighting and great colors. All those things, all those little things, they've always given us market superiority. We're going to put them to work for the first time in a straightforward casino, not a destination-integrated resort, which involves all those bells and whistles that are so expensive that you're familiar with in the past. So don't misunderstand the assignment that we have or our clear vision of what we have to do. I don't know if that makes you feel any better. Are you owning our stock these days?

componenttext: Well, we're going to do it real quick because it's not a high-rise hotel. We're going to get off, we're going out of the blocks as quickly as we can. I'm testifying we have some conditions on that we met. But I'm testifying next Wednesday in Harrisburg.

componenttext: Just a couple of questions if I may, Steve. Could you comment on just general conditions in China at the moment? There are a lot of analysts who've been writing about a VIP bubble and real estate prices having hit a peak. What are your thoughts on how you're thinking about the macro environment in Macau now?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Ian, I know you're up. What you think about that question? Here's Ian Coughlan, the CEO of Macau, is on the call. I'd love to have you hear from him.
componenttext: Ian, I know you're up. What you think about that question? Here's Ian Coughlan, the CEO of Macau, is on the call. I'd love to have you hear from him.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: I think in the three and half years I've been in Macau, there's constant stories percolating about restrained activity, liquidity issues, visa restrictions, and the market continues to grow. When I look ahead over the next 12 months, we've had a very good
componenttext: I think in the three and half years I've been in Macau, there's constant stories percolating about restrained activity, liquidity issues, visa restrictions, and the market continues to grow. When I look ahead over the next 12 months, we've had a very good start to the year. Encore is the only casino property opening in Macau in 2010. So we have a pretty optimistic view ahead. What happens in China, it's hard to predict the times, but looking ahead, we believe strongly in Macau and we feel we're going to have a good year.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: If the first two months of this year were any better, I'd be suspicious. If we go straight ahead where we have been, and incidentally, we're not holding an eye. Roll then load, is that right, John? What are we holding the first two months? I'm going to ma
componenttext: If the first two months of this year were any better, I'd be suspicious. If we go straight ahead where we have been, and incidentally, we're not holding an eye. Roll then load, is that right, John? What are we holding the first two months? I'm going to make a forward-looking statement. I'm going to give you a look at the first [indiscernible] (38:04). Clearly, we're at 2.8. And our earnings are up an enormous amount and I'm just delighted. Our franchise in Macau is real. Our customers know and expect us to be consistent and we do not disappoint them.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: You know, Steve, what I don't think everyone understands is -- it's Marc Shorr speaking. That 48% of our EBITDA dollars look comes from general casino and slots alone, not just VIP.
componenttext: You know, Steve, what I don't think everyone understands is -- it's Marc Shorr speaking. That 48% of our EBITDA dollars look comes from general casino and slots alone, not just VIP.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: That's right, but our general casino customer is different than the other general casino customer by a lot. By a lot. And I'd like to say that 3x, by a lot. We build a better mousetrap, so to speak. We build a facility more user-friendly. And there's noth
componenttext: That's right, but our general casino customer is different than the other general casino customer by a lot. By a lot. And I'd like to say that 3x, by a lot. We build a better mousetrap, so to speak. We build a facility more user-friendly. And there's nothing left in our business but to do the basics better. People come to a casino with a very specific and clear cut goal in mind. They want to sit down, enjoy the excitement of gambling, have something good to eat and be well-served. That sounds very simple, except that's not usually what happens. They want to be able to see the cards, the lighting's got to be right, they want an environment that's emotionally pleasing to them, which has to do with colors and all kinds of minute details that take years and years and years of experience to learn about. And we've got years and years and years of experience that we've learned about it. It's unfortunately not the kind of a thing that you can pick up in three weeks with a big bankroll and a bombastic wave of your arm. Nobody becomes master of the universe in this business just because they say they are. Bigger ain't better. Better is better.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from the line of Dennis Farrell with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Dennis Farrell with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: First question is, do you plan on financing Philadelphia through an unrestricted subsidiary area of one resort or through the Wynn Las Vegas level? And second is in terms of strategy, as you forward -- obviously, this is your big foray, back into the regi
componenttext: First question is, do you plan on financing Philadelphia through an unrestricted subsidiary area of one resort or through the Wynn Las Vegas level? And second is in terms of strategy, as you forward -- obviously, this is your big foray, back into the regional markets, Steve, do you potentially see looking at other greenfield opportunities throughout the U.S. to drive demand to Vegas or maybe their acquisitions?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: On the financing, side it would be through unrestricted subsidiary project finance, similar to what we've done. Not at the Wynn Las Vegas level.
componenttext: On the financing, side it would be through unrestricted subsidiary project finance, similar to what we've done. Not at the Wynn Las Vegas level.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: And the second part of your question, the answer is yes. I think that we really know that region. I don't want to use a two self-serving a term, but I will. We dominated the Atlantic City market for the seven years we were there. We got us to the fact tha
componenttext: And the second part of your question, the answer is yes. I think that we really know that region. I don't want to use a two self-serving a term, but I will. We dominated the Atlantic City market for the seven years we were there. We got us to the fact that we were the smallest casino. Not one single quarter did we not make more money than the other guys in spite of how many places opened. We loved the South Jersey market. We liked the Philadelphia market. And Atlantic City was a difficult place for us for a number of reasons, unfortunately. It had to do with a local planning and environmental sort of a community leadership. We think that this location on the Delaware River next to Society Hill and the Walt Whitman Bridge is a dandy. We like it a lot. We like being so close to the customers that we served when we were in Atlantic City in the early in mid-80s. I'm very happy about that. And I think Mark looked at that and I think in our current customer base, we had 107,000 rated players in the neighborhood within 60 minutes of that casino. And we know those people. We know what they like. And it also provide some benefit to us here in Las Vegas because we can offer them the chance to come here because we have a more intimate relationship with them. And if another regional opportunity presents itself that we understand, we will jump on it, because we got the capital and the experience to do so.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Katz with Oppenheimer.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Stephen, your opening comments you use the word mature or maturing relative to the Macau market. And I wanted to try and place that in some kind of a relative basis because early on or earlier stages we may have seen growth rates that are 30%, 40%, 50%. A
componenttext: Stephen, your opening comments you use the word mature or maturing relative to the Macau market. And I wanted to try and place that in some kind of a relative basis because early on or earlier stages we may have seen growth rates that are 30%, 40%, 50%. And perhaps now, by maturing, and I don't want to put words in your mouth, you may mean something more in the teens, which if we put that perhaps in the U.S. market it would seem robust and I just wanted to get a sense for that?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I didn't mean it that way. I was talking about the maturing in the sense of the facilities that were available to choices. One of the reasons Las Vegas has been so successful for so many years is the public has had a wonderful menu of choices.
componenttext: I'm sorry, I didn't mean it that way. I was talking about the maturing in the sense of the facilities that were available to choices. One of the reasons Las Vegas has been so successful for so many years is the public has had a wonderful menu of choices. Not one hotel but several that were all different and had a variety of options available to tourists. Macau was very limited when it was a monopoly. And then as the years have come by, since the opening of the Sands and then ourselves and the people from Melbourne, and then this past year, the Four Seasons opened, the Sands people opened the Four Seasons and the Melco people opened the City Of Dreams, that's what I meant by maturity. And then here we come with this sexy little thing called Encore. These are wonderful choices. I noticed that business for Chinese New Year was a little softer, even though Baccarat was good last year. And I think one of the reasons is that business exploded for Chinese New Year in Macau. And I think it's because now the choices in China are so wonderful for people that live in South China, they can go to Macau, they don't have to travel all the way to Las Vegas. Now again, we had a very big Baccarat year last year in Las Vegas in spite of everything else. But I'm convinced that the choices that are presenting themselves to people in Asia just as the government intended, the reason they broke the monopoly and added a couple of more concessions was so that Macau would become more attractive to a broader range of people. And that's exactly what's happening, and that's the kind maturity I was talking about. As far as growth rate, Macau is jumping this year. What's happened is growth rate is keeping up with the expansion. The more places are resulting in more business by a lot. That's what we're seeing at least in this first quarter.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: In an instantaneous heartbeat. We're more of a Chinese company than an American company today as we're having this call. I love it. Thank God for being outside the United States today. There isn't an executive in the world that isn't thrilled about being
componenttext: In an instantaneous heartbeat. We're more of a Chinese company than an American company today as we're having this call. I love it. Thank God for being outside the United States today. There isn't an executive in the world that isn't thrilled about being outside the United States today. What are we supposed to do, draw great hope and satisfaction from the behavior of the Senate and House of Representatives? If that isn't enough to give you a heartburn, I don't know what is. I don't think anybody in America is arguing. There's a furiousness in the country about the irresponsibility. $100 million a month we're supposed to borrow, $100 billion a month we're supposed to borrow for the next five or six years. Why it's totally unsustainable. It's lunacy. I remember the Lexus-Totoca [ph] bill, I think it was around 1909, the great political philosopher from France wrote, "The American's system of democracy will thrive until that moment when the politicians discover they can bribe the electorate with their own money." And those damn fools have done it.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010

componenttext: No, we didn't have disruption, we were able to build it from the outside, Larry. And it's come along great, it's on budget on time. We're going to open it up on May 21. It will be open for Memorial Day.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you can talk a little bit about timing of Cotai just given the gross in that market balanced again to restart of a couple of another projects. Is your design process at this point the real timing issue or if other, passing that market. I guess
componenttext: I wonder if you can talk a little bit about timing of Cotai just given the gross in that market balanced again to restart of a couple of another projects. Is your design process at this point the real timing issue or if other, passing that market. I guess if you could share thought process with us.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: We're very keen about our Cotai project. We think it conceivably could be the most beautiful hotel in the world after Encore, which opens up this year. And we can't think of a better place to build it, all things considered, namely the workforce and gover
componenttext: We're very keen about our Cotai project. We think it conceivably could be the most beautiful hotel in the world after Encore, which opens up this year. And we can't think of a better place to build it, all things considered, namely the workforce and government policies. We are constrained by the political process itself of getting the entitlements and details done through planning and public works in Macau, we're full-tilt. And our own planning process, it's an ambitious project it will involve a couple of billion dollars. But it's not 4,000 to 5,000 rooms or anything like that, it's one hotel on a property. It has some very novel and new ideas. So we're taking our time with the design Robin because we design the hotel first then we build it. We raise our money before we break ground so that when we do start to build it, we have all of our money together. Now I know these are sort old-fashioned concepts, design the hotel before you build it, and have the money before you start. But we're in the process of doing all that. And I think it's going to take another several months before we can answer specific questions that you're asking me today.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: One other question about Las Vegas and I know you definitely made a very clear point how you feel the economy impacting things. But I wonder to the degree that grew business on the books, you have a little bit more visibility on than in lower [ph] REVPAR.
componenttext: One other question about Las Vegas and I know you definitely made a very clear point how you feel the economy impacting things. But I wonder to the degree that grew business on the books, you have a little bit more visibility on than in lower [ph] REVPAR. Is there a point -- is it too early to say that maybe 2011 would be better, in other words higher 2011 booking versus 2010, or just any comments on volume of bookings or rate bookings for 2010 or 11? Just to get a sense of whether you see that change at all.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: If you're talking about strictly convention booking, you can say that '10 is better than '09, and you can say you see a trend of increased bookings. It is totally irresponsible and naive for anybody to say based upon this slight trend we project this infi
componenttext: If you're talking about strictly convention booking, you can say that '10 is better than '09, and you can say you see a trend of increased bookings. It is totally irresponsible and naive for anybody to say based upon this slight trend we project this infinitely into the future and give you some rosy baloney story about what's going to happen in '11. And I am warning my investors that maybe on the call to the extent that you hear any of that from our competitors, beware. There are more questions of foot in this market in America that will impact '11. And I have hair in my head, I'm happy to say and I still have a full head of hair. No, you'll not get any of that from us. I don't see it. I've got more questions than answers. I have more pessimism than I've had before and it's based upon the political environment in which we are living today. And it definitely is impacting Las Vegas. The President of the United States hasn't missed one single opportunity to squelch to Las Vegas. In our particular case, it's cost us millions of dollars from companies affected by the President's remarks that had no connection whatsoever to Federal bailouts. But we get phone calls and I'm not going to mention the names of the companies from Chairman who say we don't want to appear to be profligate because Barack Obama said this or that about Las Vegas. But it's had an effect on us. The hospitality industry in the United States of America as a whole has suffered disproportionately during this recession. Maybe automobile workers got a break, but all of that hundreds and hundreds of thousands of people that work in hotels, restaurants and bars in the United States of America had been totally and completely overlooked. And this abortive rescue attempt that is squandered billions of dollars in the United States. And I'm being very harsh about it and I've got the data to back it up, and so is everybody else in the hospitality industry. The job formation and the kinds of companies that make jobs are under attack in the United States of America. MGM, aside for a moment, last year we created almost 5,000 jobs and immediately became the target of the administration. Businesses that create a job let alone gaming companies that greater jobs had to be no good. It is preposterous that businesses are under attack in the United States of America. Anybody that makes over $250,000 in the form of a personal income tax return is now by, Washington definition, are rich person. When everybody who has got a college degree knows that the personal income tax rate in the United States of America is the business tax of America. Every Subchapter S, every individual proprietorship and every partnership in the United States of America files tax returns as individuals. And when they do, and they showed that they made $2 million or $3 million or God forbid, $4 million. They pay the income tax rate, they deduct their working expenses, they're living expenses and then they invest in a new store, a new shop. And most of the time 25% of their profits "are tied up in accounts receivable or inventory." But all of a sudden, all of those people who make over $250,000 are rich folks to be fleeced. And if that's job formation stimulation in America, I'm Mary Poppins. And if I sound angry about it and discussed it, I am disgusted and angry at the apparent ignorance of the administration and the Congress to recognize the fact that the individual tax rate in the United States of America is in fact the business tax of America. And if you keep banging on that, you will destroy the incentive for job formation in the United States of America. And that's simple truth, simple truth. And whether politicians like it or don't like it, means nothing to me. And that's why I'm pessimistic about Las Vegas, because those are our customers. Those people out there hustling there businesses and God forbid, showing that they made a million dollars as a partnership or as an individual. Yes, they're the enemy now. They're the rich folks. Well, until they get over this, Americas in for hard times because what's going to happen is the people that are going to suffer from what's going on are the working class of America. My 15,000 to 20,000 employees, they're the ones that are in trouble. The reason they're in trouble is this demolition of the dollar, is going to reduce the buying power of the working class of America as sure as hell as if we gave them a salary cut of 25%. And that's another thing that doesn't seem to be clear to the brilliant people in Washington DC. They're not just our customers, they are my employees. And until my employees get the drifts of what's being done to them, America's in trouble.

componenttext: We don't have any trouble raising capital worldwide, you know we financed China a 100% with Asian financing. I'm happy to say those organization is a lot deeper than just me, I just want to shoot my mouth of today. And if you're politically sensitive, you're probably cringing at my criticism of the government, but it's become a factor in our life everyday on the job here. As far as my time is concerned, I don't think that Philadelphia, it that's what we're talking about is detractive. I think that's a constructive use of my time and I'll certainly have time when and if opportunities. I mean I work on Philadelphia and I work on Cotai, that's basically what I do now along with everything else that goes along with being a CEO of the parent company. But we find that very comfortable, our capacity.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: And then if you take a view on Cotai, with regard to Galaxy sites five and six. I mean a lot of supply, and I know that you're sensually viewing Macau at least it sounds likes as supply driven. But from a broad strategy point of view, is Cotai where you r
componenttext: And then if you take a view on Cotai, with regard to Galaxy sites five and six. I mean a lot of supply, and I know that you're sensually viewing Macau at least it sounds likes as supply driven. But from a broad strategy point of view, is Cotai where you really begin to go after the mass player and the Peninsula will become even more focused on VIP? Will it change your strategy for Wynn Macau or Wynn Encore?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: I love the idea that their going to starts five and six because it's a Sheraton, their lower end products, and that's lots of folks. And then they, Sheldon, built all those ferry boats, I think that's good too. And he was subsidizing everybody else on Cot
componenttext: I love the idea that their going to starts five and six because it's a Sheraton, their lower end products, and that's lots of folks. And then they, Sheldon, built all those ferry boats, I think that's good too. And he was subsidizing everybody else on Cotai by those ferry boats and it's also worked out well for him. That's all great stuff, it all happened and what I'm looking forward to is opening the nicest place in that neighborhood and skimming off the top end of the business just like we did downtown in Las Vegas on the Strip, in Atlantic City and we're doing it now in Macau. That's our stick, we do that. We love overdeveloped markets, it's where we thrive.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: So one question on Singapore competition. There seem marketing concern that Singapore is going after directly at new market Wynn Macau is very strong about, so what's your take on that? And do you see any threat potentially going forward? And also what is
componenttext: So one question on Singapore competition. There seem marketing concern that Singapore is going after directly at new market Wynn Macau is very strong about, so what's your take on that? And do you see any threat potentially going forward? And also what is the percentage of a VIP customer actually coming from the Southeast Asia?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, your questions well put, and if I could rephrase it. Is Singapore is designed to take the top end customer away from us, four hours away in a jet, the equivalent of New York to L.A. Are we worried? Now this hotel in Singapore is going to be
componenttext: First of all, your questions well put, and if I could rephrase it. Is Singapore is designed to take the top end customer away from us, four hours away in a jet, the equivalent of New York to L.A. Are we worried? Now this hotel in Singapore is going to be beautiful, I hope, I suspect that it will be. It's going to open up in April, the one that the Venetian folks have built. Now right down on the street for 25 minutes from our hotel in Macau, the same company built the Four Seasons designed by their own public announcement to take our business away. People didn't have to travel four hours on a jet. They decided to do it right down the street. And they weren't able to do it. So I hardly can be concerned about a threat of four hours by jet away from me if I wasn't concerned about one that was 4 miles away from me on Cotai.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: How about for the southeast Asia customer percentage?
componenttext: How about for the southeast Asia customer percentage?

componenttextpreview: It's less than 5%.
componenttext: It's less than 5%.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Of the overall VIP?
componenttext: Of the overall VIP?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Our customers are from China and Singapore is further away. They did a clever thing with the taxation in Singapore. I think that Singapore will develop its own market closer to itself in a very organic and well considered way. But to think of the two casi
componenttext: Our customers are from China and Singapore is further away. They did a clever thing with the taxation in Singapore. I think that Singapore will develop its own market closer to itself in a very organic and well considered way. But to think of the two casinos in Macau and Singapore as a direct threat to Macau, I think is to misunderstand the Singapore market. I am very optimistic about the Singapore market, don't misunderstand me. But I think the Singapore market will be Malaysian, I think it would be Indonesian and I think it would be that sort of thing and Thailand and even Brunei, those places that are close within an hour or two. That's how it works for Macau and that's how it will work for Singapore, and you can count the amount of people within the range that I just described and you can take a look at their ethnicity. There's a big Muslim population that part of the world and you can consider what the size of that market will be. But I don't think -- don't look at Singapore versus Macau in terms of taking customers away. I think you'll miss the boat on that one.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Charles Coakley with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Charles Coakley with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: That being said, looking backwards at the Encore, the hopes that you had in the beginning, of course, the rug was pulled out under all of us with the political climate and what happened to the economy. Is it what you thought it would be and is it helping
componenttext: That being said, looking backwards at the Encore, the hopes that you had in the beginning, of course, the rug was pulled out under all of us with the political climate and what happened to the economy. Is it what you thought it would be and is it helping Wynn? And how do you feel long-term about the strength of the Twins next to each other?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-25-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's not what I thought it would be. I thought that it would add at least $200 million or $250 million of EBITDA to our bottom line and nothing remotely like that has happened. Of course, it was conceived in a market that was entirely different today,
componenttext: No, it's not what I thought it would be. I thought that it would add at least $200 million or $250 million of EBITDA to our bottom line and nothing remotely like that has happened. Of course, it was conceived in a market that was entirely different today, as you've just pointed out. It is a beautiful thing that cost $2.3 billion. Now, we made a certain amount of money last year in Las Vegas. That money -- we made more money than that without Encore, let alone with it. So now you have to ask yourself a question. If we had no Encore, if we didn't have those other 2,000 other rooms, would we have made even less? Or would we just be better off because we did, we would have had $2.3 billion in cash more than we do now. I would love to have the ability to reconsider that decision at the moment, but I don't. I know this that there's a wonderful powerful synergy that we're seeing in people that stay at Encore and love it and come back. They're not paying enough for the rooms to suit me and to suit our pro forma, but neither is that happening anywhere else in America that I know of or in Europe. So would I build Encore if I had to do it today, no, I'd keep my money. Fortunately, we had enough money that we don't sweat it. We had planned that business cycles go up, business cycles go down. Any sophisticated company plans and has built into its capital structure, an ability to survive such a predictable events. So when Encore opened, we were ready. I don't know when Encore's power will kick in at full tilt. I know that when the Beach Club opens up in a few months, that we're going to have a lot more people in Encore than we do now, especially on that side, on the Strip side of the property. And that those tables and those slot machines are going to be much more fully utilized and there's going to be a big profit margin in the Beach Club and the Surrender Nightclub and then the Switch restaurant. And there will be a lot more excitement on the north end of the Strip because of facade and the structure itself that anchor our landholdings here on the Strip. So I'm very happy about what we've added to Encore. But as far as the rooms and what they're doing for us, we're on hold here. And as I said before, I think we're on hold for a while, unless the government in Washington gives the world a message that America -- Lee Kuan Yew, speaking of Singapore, was in the United States and went to visit the President of the United States. Before the day before he went to visit the President, he was on television on Charlie Rose's show. And Charlie Rose asked this brilliant most elder statesman in the world, the man who founded Singapore, he asked Lee Kuan Yew, what about America and what advice would you give the President of the United States. And this sage Mount Rushmore caliber man said on television on PBS, and I'm sure he repeated it in the White House but I wasn't there of course, he said, unless the government and the administration can learn to control government expenditures, they're wildly out of control. The value of the dollar will be decimated and destroyed to the detriment of the people, of the world and the United States in the world. That's what he said. And until we have a signal that such discipline and common sense has regained its footing, I don't know how to answer the kinds of questions that you're asking. And I don't think other any other businessman does either.
